lesion_morphology.border: Generally well-demarcated individual lesions; background erythema in Rosacea is diffuse.
lesion_morphology.texture: Varies from smooth (closed comedones) to bumpy/inflamed (papules/pustules) and firm (nodules).
lesion_morphology.key_distinctions: Presence of comedones is pathognomonic for Acne Vulgaris. Absence of comedones with persistent central facial erythema and telangiectasias is key for Rosacea.

visual_cues.distribution: Sebaceous gland areas (face, chest, back) for Acne Vulgaris; central facial for Rosacea.
visual_cues.pattern: Polymorphic lesions (multiple types at once) are common in Acne Vulgaris.
visual_cues.special_signs: Flushing and blushing history is a strong indicator for Rosacea.

demographics.sex_ratio: M:F ≈ 1:1 in teens; F > M in adult acne and Rosacea.

time_dynamics.onset: Chronic with flares. Acne Vulgaris often starts at puberty. Rosacea often starts in adulthood.
time_dynamics.seasonality: Acne Vulgaris can worsen in winter. Rosacea is often triggered by sun/heat.

red_flags: Acne fulminans (severe, ulcerative, with fever/systemic symptoms)
Sudden adult onset (may indicate underlying endocrine issue)

confounder_questions.question: Are there blackheads or whiteheads (comedones) present?
Is the redness persistent in the central face and do you flush easily?
Is the rash very itchy and composed of uniform small bumps, mainly on the chest and back?

differential.distinguishing_feature: Monomorphic, itchy papules/pustules, no comedones, often on chest/back.
Papules clustered around mouth/nose, sparing the vermilion border.
Ill-defined borders, significant itch, often in flexural areas.

lesion_morphology.texture: Thick, silvery-white scale on an erythematous base (Psoriasis); smooth, flat-topped with fine white lines (LP).
lesion_morphology.key_distinctions: Psoriasis: Erythematous plaques with silvery scale on extensor surfaces. Lichen Planus: Violaceous, polygonal, pruritic papules (4 P's) on flexural surfaces with Wickham's striae (fine white reticular lines).

visual_cues.distribution: Symmetrical. Psoriasis favors extensor surfaces. Lichen Planus favors flexural surfaces (wrists, ankles) and oral mucosa.
visual_cues.pattern: Discrete plaques that can become confluent.
visual_cues.special_signs: Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding on scale removal) & Koebner phenomenon (lesions at site of trauma) for Psoriasis. Wickham's striae for Lichen Planus.

time_dynamics.seasonality: Psoriasis often worsens in winter and improves with sun.

confounder_questions.question: Are the patches thick, red, and covered with a silvery-white scale?
Are the patches mainly on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees?
Does the rash look like a ring with a clearing center and a scaly edge?

differential.distinguishing_feature: Ill-defined borders, intense pruritus, flexural distribution, history of atopy.
Greasy, yellowish scale in sebaceous areas (scalp, face), less demarcation.
Annular (ring-shaped) with central clearing and an active, raised border.

reference_images.kaggle_dataset: Psoriasis Pictures, Lichen Planus and related diseases

lesion_morphology.border: Ill-defined, indistinct borders that blend into normal skin.
lesion_morphology.texture: Dry, scaly, rough. Acutely can be weepy/bubbly. Chronically can be thickened/leathery.
lesion_morphology.key_distinctions: The hallmark is poorly demarcated erythema with significant pruritus (itch). Presentation varies by subtype: flexural in atopic, geometric/patterned in contact, coin-shaped in nummular, vesicles on hands/feet in dyshidrotic.

visual_cues.distribution: Classic flexural involvement (creases of elbows, knees) in atopic. Can be anywhere depending on subtype.
visual_cues.pattern: Diffuse patches (atopic), geometric shapes (contact), or coin-shaped (nummular).

demographics.age_peak: Typically starts in childhood (<5 years), can persist or appear in adults.

time_dynamics.onset: Chronic, relapsing-remitting course. Often associated with personal/family history of asthma, hay fever (atopic triad).
time_dynamics.seasonality: Often worse in dry, cold winter months.

red_flags: Sudden worsening with widespread vesicles or pustules (may indicate secondary bacterial or viral infection, e.g., eczema herpeticum).

confounder_questions.question: Are the borders of the rash blurry and ill-defined?
Is the rash located in flexural areas like the crooks of your elbows or backs of your knees?
Do you or your close family members have a history of asthma or hay fever?

differential.distinguishing_feature: Well-demarcated plaques, silvery scale, less itch, extensor distribution.
Annular shape, central clearing, active border, confirmed by KOH test.
Intense nocturnal itch, burrows in web spaces, household contacts affected.

lesion_morphology.border: Variable: well-demarcated vesicles (HSV), irregular (HPV), indurated/defined (Syphilitic chancre).
lesion_morphology.key_distinctions: HSV: Grouped painful vesicles on an erythematous base. HPV: Flesh-colored to pink verrucous (warty) papules. Syphilis: Painless, indurated chancre (primary) or a non-pruritic, coppery rash including palms/soles (secondary).

visual_cues.distribution: Typically localized to site of contact (anogenital, oral). Secondary syphilis is widespread.
visual_cues.pattern: Grouped/clustered vesicles (HSV), scattered or confluent papules (HPV), solitary ulcer (primary syphilis), symmetric rash (secondary syphilis).
visual_cues.special_signs: Involvement of palms and soles is a classic sign of secondary syphilis.

time_dynamics.onset: Acute onset following exposure. HSV is classically recurrent/latent. Syphilis progresses in stages if untreated.

triggers: Stress or immunosuppression can trigger HSV recurrence.
red_flags: Neurologic or ocular symptoms (neurosyphilis, ocular herpes)

confounder_questions.question: Are the lesions painful, clustered blisters or vesicles?
Is there a single, firm, painless ulcer?
Have you noticed a widespread rash that also involves the palms of your hands and soles of your feet?

differential.distinguishing_feature: Painful ulcers only inside the mouth on non-keratinized mucosa, not preceded by vesicles.
Small, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication.
Recurrent, painful oral and genital ulcers plus other systemic signs (uveitis, skin lesions).

reference_images.kaggle_dataset: Herpes, HPV, and other STDs Photos

lesion_morphology.border: Sharply demarcated, active, raised border (Tinea); ill-defined with satellite lesions (Candidiasis).
lesion_morphology.texture: Scaly, sometimes with tiny vesicles or pustules at the active edge.
lesion_morphology.key_distinctions: Tinea ('Ringworm'): Annular (ring-shaped) lesion with central clearing and an active, scaling border. Candidiasis: Bright red erythema in skin folds (intertrigo) with characteristic satellite papules/pustules.

visual_cues.distribution: Asymmetric. Tinea is named by location (pedis=feet, cruris=groin). Candidiasis favors moist, occluded areas (inframammary, groin, axillae).
visual_cues.pattern: Annular with central clearing is classic for Tinea. Satellite lesions are classic for Candidiasis.
visual_cues.special_signs: A 'leading edge' of scale is highly suggestive of a dermatophyte infection.

demographics.age_peak: Any age. Tinea capitis common in children. Tinea pedis/cruris in young adults. Candidiasis common in infants (diaper) and immunocompromised.

red_flags: Widespread infection in an immunocompromised patient.
Kerion formation (inflammatory, boggy mass) in tinea capitis.
Failure to respond to topical antifungals (may be incorrect diagnosis or resistant organism).

confounder_questions.question: Does the rash have a distinct ring-like shape with a clearing center and a scaly, active border?
Is the rash bright red, located in a skin fold (like under the breasts or in the groin), and surrounded by smaller 'satellite' spots?
Did the rash get significantly worse after applying a steroid cream (like hydrocortisone)?

differential.distinguishing_feature: Coin-shaped but typically lacks central clearing and has a weepy/crusted surface, not a scaling edge.
Thicker, silvery scale, not annular, typically symmetrical on extensor surfaces.
Well-demarcated brown-red patches in skin folds, fluoresces coral-red under Wood's lamp.

reference_images.kaggle_dataset: Tinea Ringworm Candidiasis and other Fungal Infections

primary: Erythematous Macule or Papule with scale (AK)
lesion_morphology.key_distinctions: BCC: Pearly papule with surface telangiectasias and often a rolled border, may have central ulceration. AK: A pre-cancerous lesion that feels like a rough, dry, sandpaper-like spot on sun-exposed skin.

visual_cues.distribution: Almost exclusively on sun-exposed areas of the body.
visual_cues.pattern: Typically solitary lesions, but fields of multiple AKs ('field cancerization') are common.
visual_cues.special_signs: A sore that bleeds, heals, and then recurs in the same spot is highly suspicious for BCC.

demographics.age_peak: Increasingly common after age 40, peak in 60s-80s.
demographics.sex_ratio: M > F, likely due to cumulative sun exposure.
demographics.skin_type: Much more common in fair-skinned individuals (Fitzpatrick I-II).

time_dynamics.onset: Very slow growing over months to years.

triggers: Chronic cumulative sun (UV) exposure is the primary cause.
red_flags: Location in high-risk 'H-zone' of face (around eyes, nose, lips, ears).

confounder_questions.question: Does the spot have a shiny, pearly, or translucent appearance with tiny blood vessels visible on the surface?
Is it a sore or pimple that bleeds, scabs over, but never fully heals?
Does the spot feel rough and dry like sandpaper when you run your finger over it?

differential.distinguishing_feature: 'Stuck-on' appearance, waxy/warty texture, no ulceration or telangiectasias.
Often arises from AK, but is typically a firmer, more crusted or ulcerated nodule that grows faster than a BCC.
Typically pigmented (brown/black), grows more rapidly.

reference_images.kaggle_dataset: Basal Cell Carcinoma and other Malignant Lesions

lesion_morphology.texture: Waxy, verrucous (warty), greasy, or velvety. Can be smooth or very rough.
lesion_morphology.key_distinctions: The single most important feature is the 'stuck-on' appearance, as if it could be picked off. They often have a warty surface with visible keratin-filled pits (horn cysts).

visual_cues.distribution: Can be anywhere except palms, soles, and mucous membranes. Often numerous.
visual_cues.special_signs: Sign of Leser-Trélat: sudden eruption of numerous SKs, can be a sign of internal malignancy (rare).

demographics.age_peak: Very common after age 40, prevalence increases with age.

time_dynamics.onset: Slow growing over years. Patient often has multiple lesions of varying ages.

triggers: Genetics and age are the primary factors. Friction can irritate them.
red_flags: Sudden eruption of many lesions (Leser-Trélat sign).
A lesion that is bleeding, itching, or rapidly changing (could be an irritated SK or a misdiagnosed melanoma).

confounder_questions.question: Does the growth look like it was pasted or 'stuck on' the surface of the skin?
Is the surface waxy, warty, or crumbly?
Is the spot a uniform color (tan, brown, or black) and has been stable for a long time?

differential.distinguishing_feature: The most important differential. Melanoma may have color variegation, irregular borders, and a history of change. An SK is typically uniform and stable. A biopsy is definitive if there is any doubt.
AKs are flat, feel like sandpaper, and are on sun-exposed skin. SKs are raised and 'stuck-on'.
Pigmented BCCs will still have other BCC features like a pearly, rolled border and telangiectasias, which SKs lack.

reference_images.kaggle_dataset: Seborrheic Keratosis and other Benign Tumors
